report_title: Online Antiques & Collectibles Sales in the US
executive_summary: Figures have been adjusted for inflation and are presented in 2024 currency. Online antiques and collectibles sellers have continued to flourish, largely because of the growing ubiquity and popularity of online shopping. Antiques and collectibles are timeless yet discretionary items, making this industry sensitive to changes in disposable income. Despite steady growth, antique and collectible item sales have historically relied on brick-and-mortar stores because of the nature of the items sold. However, this was disrupted by COVID-19, as consumers shifted their preferences toward online shopping. Revenue for online antiques and collectibles sellers is expected to climb at a CAGR of 9.1% to $2.6 billion through the end of 2024, including growth of 1.6% in 2024. The strong expansion in sales has supported profit growth.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: COVID-19 Changed the Game for How Antiques Are Purchased
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Despite COVID-19's economic downturn, the online antiques and collectibles industry surged as sales swiftly transitioned from physical stores to online platforms. After making an online purchase for the first time, consumers are more likely to do it again. Investors in antiques and collectibles prefer online platforms over traditional physical stores because of their lower prices and more comprehensive selections.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: ANTIQUES AND COLLECTIBLES ARE PURELY DISCRETIONARY ITEMS
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: The industry is highly sensitive to changes in disposable income since antiques and collectibles are discretionary goods used for collection, aesthetic and investment purposes. Disposable incomes have climbed alongside strong labor markets and general economic growth in recent years. Following the Federal Reserve's decision to aggressively raise benchmark interest rates multiple times in recent years, a tighter policy has affected budgets and caused some volatility in disposable income. Until inflation eases, the cost of living will continue to be high, affecting disposable income levels.

Smartphones and other mobile technologies have made it easier for consumers to purchase products online, further stimulating demand for online retailers. As the number of mobile connections continues to swell, more consumers can easily connect with online sellers. Increases in online payment security boosted this trend by making consumers feel confident in the reliability and safety of the online shopping process. Providing secure transactions is one of the primary reasons that consumers use online antiques and collectibles sellers.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: INTENSE COMPETITION CREATES PRESSURE ON ONLINE RETAILERS
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Companies have been aggressively competing based on price and investing heavily in advertising to distinguish themselves from competitors. Low barriers to entry and skill requirements enable companies to enter the industry actively. However, the industry benefits from an expanding market, which offers more opportunities for online retailers specializing in niche items like comic books, vintage toys, and collectible coins.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: ECONOMIC FLUCTUATION WILL CONTINUE TO CAUSE VOLATILITY
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: According to Forbes Advisor, The New York Fed recession probability indicator shows there is still a 66.0% chance of a US recession in 2024, causing some uncertainty for buyers of antiques and collectibles. During economic uncertainty, consumers are more likely to spend money on necessities than on discretionary items like antiques and collectibles. Sellers can limit volatility by focusing on time-tested favorites, like sports memorabilia.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: ONLINE RETAILERS WILL CONTINUE TO EMPLOY TECHNOLOGY TO REMAIN COMPETITIVE
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Online retailers will leverage technology through acquisitions or partnerships, particularly in blockchain, machine learning and databases. Blockchain technology will help verify the authenticity of antiques and collectibles. This could reduce fraud and build greater trust between buyers and sellers. This technology will improve product-consumer matching, boosting sales and addressing privacy and payment concerns in a time of rising cybersecurity threats. However, it may also intensify competition and pressure profit.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: INCREASED REGULATION WILL BOOST OPERATIONAL COSTS
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Regulatory changes may require online retailers to shift the burden of sales tax collection. This regulatory shift will boost operations costs, reduce profit and jeopardize the business model of online antiques and collectibles sales. Smaller companies will be hit hard, as they will need to hire tax specialists to ensure compliance, thereby increasing operational costs. Profit is already relatively modest, which could force some companies out of the industry.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: THE INTERNET CONTINUES TO SHAPE THE INDUSTRY
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: The internet has made it easier for sellers to reach international buyers. Expanding globalization means a broader audience for antiques and collectibles, increasing competition while also opening up new markets. Social media influencers focusing on vintage and collectible items will shape consumer preferences. Followers trust their recommendations, which will drive traffic to online sales platforms. Online communities and social media groups dedicated to antiques and collectibles will foster discussions, reviews and recommendations. In the coming years, these communities will strengthen the relationship between buyers and sellers and enhance customer loyalty.

industry_definition: This industry retails or auctions antiques and collectibles, including coins, jewelry, books, figurines and memorabilia. This industry does not include online sales and auctions of original art pieces.

negative_impact_factors: Low - Steady Barriers To Entry Level

key_trends: The industry exhibits a moderate level of competition. Companies primarily compete based on product offerings, shipping fees, delivery options and customer service.

Sellers endure external competition from traditional brick-and-mortar stores and big-box retailers. The intensity of this competition hinges on factors like efficiency, price and product availability.

Amid COVID-19, the sellers benefited from a surge as sales shifted from in-person to online platforms. Lower costs, broader choices and the accessibility of mobile technologies facilitated the change.

Economic uncertainty could impact the market for antiques, with prospective buyers prioritizing necessities. Also, regulatory changes like sales tax collection may escalate costs for online retailers, threatening their existing business models.
eBay keeps costs low by encouraging antiques and collectibles sellers to conduct business on their website. Users can list items for sale or auction and generate revenue through their eBay page.
Heritage Auctions Inc. has conducted numerous high-profile sales encompassing rare coins, fine art and iconic collectibles. The company's headquarters are in Dallas, Texas.

Online antiques and collectibles sellers aren't heavily regulated. Online retailers must adhere to federal and state privacy, security and taxation regulations. The industry doesn't have any major grants or subsidies.
Profit has been boosted by a surge in demand. Revenue skyrocketed during the pandemic when brick-and-mortar shops were closed. Growing levels of competition have constrained profit growth.
The industry's principal expense is purchase costs. Sellers must acquire collectibles and antiques and purchase costs are driven up by online retailers competing for a low supply of coveted items.

Unlike traditional retail, online sellers don't rely on proximity to customers. For online antiques and collectibles sellers, warehouse space is important, making market proximity an advantage, not a necessity. Online retailers strategically position their warehouses near key import or export centers to facilitate trade.
Antiques command high prices because of their rarity. However, online sales for contemporary collectibles, including novelty items.

market_segmentation.segment_description: Despite their relatively lower disposable income levels, consumers aged 18-34 are a tech-savvy demographic adapting to online antiques and collectibles sales faster than older age groups. Accustomed to online shopping, these consumers connect with online antiques and collectibles retailers via social media and other virtual platforms.

Consumers in this age demographic have slightly contracted as a share of overall demand, as older age cohorts have become more comfortable making online purchases as COVID-19 limited in-person purchases. Consumers aged 35-54 often prefer shopping at physical antique and collectible stores. Most of the consumers in this cohort have steady jobs and high disposable income, enabling them to spend more on discretionary purchases, including antique and collectible items.

Despite an interest in antiques and collectibles and relatively high levels of disposable income, consumers aged 55 and older are less likely to make major purchases online compared with younger shoppers. They are wary of online purchases of antiques and collectibles because of perceived security concerns. Many in this group have accumulated sizable collections of antique and collectible items and prefer personal attention and professional knowledge.

products_and_services.product_description: An antique is a collectible item of significant age. According to US Customs and Border Protection, such an item is considered an antique if it is over 100 years old at the time of importation.
Some consumers and online shops may label any older collectible items as antiques and price them accordingly. Sales for antique items have decreased.

A collectible is a valuable or interesting object consumers seek, not for its monetary value but for its rarity or uniqueness. The entire segment of collectibles comprises world currencies, sports collectibles, comics and animation art.

There are two classifications of collectibles: Novelty items, typically out of production, evoke nostalgia. Contemporary collectibles, on the other hand, are intentionally manufactured for collection and often carry special edition tags.

Consumers can visit online antiques and collectibles marketplaces to find vintage rings, necklaces, bracelets and timepieces. These items are especially popular with consumers looking for ethically sourced and sustainable luxury products.
Antique and collectible wines can fetch extraordinary prices on the market. Sellers specializing in vintage wine sales will typically have a list of clients to

tier_2_buyers: Used Goods Stores in the US

demand_determinants.determinant_description: During periods of low economic growth, consumer confidence declines, and consumers limit their expenditure on discretionary products. Spending shifts toward necessary items, like groceries and prescription medications. Changes in the consumer confidence index directly influence sales of antiques and collectibles. Growth in the consumer confidence index represents a potential opportunity for the industry.

business_locations.location_description: Online retailers typically want to keep their warehouses near major import or export centers. In the West region, companies are adjacent to the Pacific market. The West region also boasts several prominent antique and collectible hubs, like Los Angeles and San Francisco, which attract numerous collectors. eBay Inc., a major influence in the industry, is headquartered in California.

The Southeast region is home to several prominent antique and collectible hubs, like Miami and Atlanta, which attract many collectors. The Southeast and Mid-Atlantic regions are the main markets for trade across the Atlantic.

The Mid-Atlantic region is rich in history and culture, with many museums, galleries and cultural institutions. The Southeast and Mid-Atlantic regions are the main markets for trade across the Atlantic.

regulations_points.regulation_description: The FTC enforces online retailers' privacy laws. Truthful advertising standards also apply to online retailers. These measures protect customers from false advertisements, ensuring transparency and authenticity. The FTC also enforces guidelines related to reasonable shipping times and refund guidelines.

In 2018, the US Supreme Court ruled in favor of the state in South Dakota v. Wayfair, Inc., allowing states to collect sales tax on digital transactions, whether or not the selling enterprise has a physical location within the state. This has increased tax liabilities for online sellers in recent years.

Online auction platforms for antiques and collectibles must comply with specific auction laws and regulations. This includes transparency in bidding processes, clear terms of sale and fair competition.

Online sales of antiques and collectibles require adherence to payment processing regulations. This includes compliance with the Payment Card Industry Data Security Standards to protect buyers' payment information.
Online platforms often require sellers to provide proof of authenticity and provenance to prevent fraud and guarantee trustworthiness.

basis_points.basis_description: Online retailers distinguish themselves based on the quality of antique products, diversity of styles and pieces, superior website design, user-friendliness and brand reputation.

concentration_points.concentration_description: Although the two largest online antique sellers account for a sizeable portion of revenue, the remaining sellers are highly fragmented.

concentration_points.concentration_title: ONLINE RETAILERS VERTICALLY INTEGRATE THEIR OPERATIONS TO ENHANCE COMPETITIVENESS
concentration_points.concentration_description: Many online antiques and collectibles sellers acquire or partner with a larger industry player for certain sales.

cost_factors.cost_factor_title: Purchases comprise the largest cost segment
cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Collectibles and antiques can be acquired through resale purchases from individuals or dealers.

cost_factors.cost_factor_title: Merchandise volumes typically mirror annual consumer sales trends
cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Merchandise volumes typically mirror annual consumer sales trends, reflecting a company's capacity to hold higher stock levels.

cost_factors.cost_factor_title: MARKETING PROVIDES A SIGNIFICANT ADVANTAGE FOR ONLINE RETAILERS
cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Major online retailers frequently depend on strategic marketing and advertising initiatives.

cost_factors.cost_factor_title: THE INDUSTRY HAS RELATIVELY LOW WAGE COSTS
cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Online retailers incur lower wages than traditional brick-and-mortar stores.

cost_factors.cost_factor_title: The Industry Profit Level Reflects the Commissions Charges of Websites
cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Websites can charge a listing fee, a percentage of the selling price or a combination of both.

capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_description: Online retailers require significant investment in servers, security and payment infrastructure.

volatility_points.volatility_description: The antiques market is quite sensitive to the US macroeconomic environment.

volatility_points.volatility_title: The pandemic fueled a heightened level of volatility
volatility_points.volatility_description: The surge in online antique sales during the pandemic is a significant driver behind the industry's current volatility.

technological_change_points.technological_change_title: ARTIFICIAL INTELLIGENCE (AI) CHANGES THE WAY SELLERS INTERACT WITH CUSTOMERS
technological_change_points.technological_change_description: Online retailers leverage AI systems to examine customer likes, actions and historical transactions.

technological_change_points.technological_change_title: VIRTUAL REALITY (VR) INCREASES THE SALES CONVERSION RATE
technological_change_points.technological_change_description: VR platforms enable individuals to explore digital replicas of antiques and collectible exhibit pieces.

FAQs.question: Does your company specialize in one corner of the market or do you retail a diversified range of products?
FAQs.answer: Industry retailers have the advantage of selling a wide array of antiques and collector's items, attracting many different types of buyers.

FAQs.question: Are your sales heavily dependent on wealthy consumers or households?
FAQs.answer: Households with incomes of $100,000 or more account for the most collectible and antiques purchases.

FAQs.question: What steps do you take to retain talented employees with specialized knowledge?
FAQs.answer: Industry companies employ workers with a wide range of skill levels and average wages.

FAQs.question: Does your company lease equipment to reduce overhead costs?
FAQs.answer: Online shopping operators outlay capital on technology to establish, implement and maintain websites.

FAQs.question: Does your company use point-of-sale (POS) systems to ensure that the most popular products are kept in stock?
FAQs.answer: Industry operators do not maintain physical storefronts, instead primarily conducting commerce through online websites.
